awd_titl_txt: CAREER: An online global monograph of Magnaporthales - evolution, taxonomy, biogeography and biology of the rice blast fungus and allies
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnaporthales, an order of fungi with over 200 species, contains important pathogens of cereals and grasses, including the rice blast fungus.  The rice blast fungus is the most destructive disease of rice, which is a staple food source for about half of the world's human population. Despite their scientific and economic importance, Magnaporthales fungi have not been studied comprehensively, and the diversity, taxonomy and evolutionary relationships of Magnaporthales species remain unsettled.  There is no consensus on which scientific name to use for these important pathogens, and this impedes communication among scientists, animal and plant health inspection services, and other user communities around the world.  Recent major changes in the international naming system for fungi have added to the confusion of names and distributions for these fungi. This project will generate molecular data and evolutionary analyses for the understudied species that will be presented in a comprehensive monograph on the Magnaporthales, which will available online to researchers and the broader user communities worldwide at no cost. This research will facilitate future work on Magnaporthales systematics, genetics, biodiversity, plant protection and quarantine feasibility.

The major objectives of this project are: 1) to sample from the understudied grassland ecosystems, and to discover, diagnose and describe new taxa in Magnaporthales using both traditional culture-based and next-generation metagenomic sequencing methods; 2) to build a robust phylogenomic tree for all Magnaporthales taxa; 3) to use the phylogeny in improving our understanding of the evolution of pathogenicity and other traits of Magnaporthales fungi; 4) to produce a global monograph of Magnaporthales; and 5) to train students and postdocs to conduct research across the entire spectrum of these activities. The project includes studies of phylogenomics, evolution, taxonomy, biodiversity, organismal biology and metagenomics. The global monograph of Magnaporthales will include: traditional morphological descriptions, diagnostic illustrations, distribution maps, host-range information, interactive identification keys to genera and species, as well as DNA barcodes. Genomic sequences for the representative taxa also will be linked to the cyber-enabled monograph. The PI will engage high school, undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral fellow, with a focus on teaching and training of underrepresented minorities.

por.por_cntn:
The order Magnaporthales is a scientifically and economically important fungal lineage. It contains over 200 species, 50% of which are pathogens of monocot plants, e.g., rice, maize and wheat. The best-studied species is the rice blast fungus, which is the most destructive disease of rice that serves as a staple food source for about half of the world population. However, taxonomy of this group of fungi remained unsettled. The major objectives of this project are: 1) to build a robust phylogenomic tree of Magnaporthales and to understand the evolution of pathogenicity and morphological and ecological characters; 2) to sample from the understudied grassland and pine barrens ecosystems in the U.S. and to discover and describe new taxa in Magnaporthales using both traditional culture-based and next-generation metagenomic sequencing methods; 3) to produce a global monograph of Magnaporthales; and 4) to train students and postdocs to conduct research across the entire spectrum of these activities.

 

This study combined the fields of phylogenomics, evolution, taxonomy, biodiversity, organismal biology and metagenomics. The comprehensive phylogenomic analysis provided a solid basis, which is necessary for a stable taxonomic framework that stands the test of time. It also will be the basis for a deep insight into the evolution of pathogenesis, and the morphological and ecological characters. 

 

Based on phylogenetic and genomic analysis, observation of herbarium specimens, and literature published in the past century on Magnaporthales fungi, the PI has completed the monograph - "The Rice Blast Fungus and Allied Species: A Monograph of the Fungal Order Magnaporthales". It includes an introduction, dichotomous keys, name recommendations, species descriptions, images and distribution maps for the type and representative species, links to gene and genome data, and other resources. The electronic version of the monograph is open to public and searchable online. Genomic sequences for the representative species also are linked to the cyber-enabled E-monograph. The PI?s lab also conducted field trips in the pine barrens ecosystem, and isolated over 1,500 fungal isolates in about 300 species, among which over 100 are undescribed. A new family, four new genera and 14 new species have been published. Fungal cultures, type specimens and sequence data have been deposited in the culture collection centers, herbarium, and GenBank, respectively. In addition, a culture-independent metabarcoding analysis pipeline has been developed and applied to root associated mycobiome analysis. 

 

The grant supported a postdoctoral associate and a PhD student. Several undergraduate students also have been trained, some of which are from families/communities disadvantaged by low income and the lack of access to the quality educational preparation necessary to attend college (supported by The New Jersey Educational Opportunity Fund program). The monograph of this important group of plant pathogens also facilitates plant protection and quarantine feasibility. 

 

Grant-Supported Publications: This grant has supported 25 papers, a monograph (both print and electronic), 3 book chapters, and 16 presentations. In addition, the grant supported an international symposium organized by the PI at Rutgers University in 2016 entitled, ?Comparative genomic approaches to understanding the evolution of Magnaporthales?, which also yielded paper publication.
